page.title: 09Local History
page.content: Being above sea level, most of this block was free from fen, so it has been inhabited for many thousands of years.{Stone Age}flint impliments have been discovered in the fields,and in the North West corner of the block is a{Bronze Age}burial mound. Kenninghall derived it's name from the fact that in this manor was a seat of the ancient East Anglian kings,King's Hall becoming Kenninghall. Kenninghall was mentioned in the first Doomesday survey in 1068,and Quidenham church exhibits{Norman}features, the round tower possibly dating from the Anglo Saxon}times. In the{Middle Ages,}the area was famous for sheep rearing,and was thus prosperous,some of the ancient timber framed houses still remaining.
